title: Weak Password Policy - No Complexity Requirements or Minimum Length
description: The registration endpoint at /register does not enforce any password complexity or length requirements. The application accepts passwords of any length, including single characters (e.g., '1', 'a'), multi-character passwords without special requirements (e.g., '12', 'abc'), and critically, empty passwords. Users can create accounts with passwords as weak as single-character strings, making brute force attacks trivial and dramatically weakening account security. No password strength validation, minimum length enforcement, complexity requirements, or dictionary checks are implemented.
impact: Weak passwords dramatically reduce account security: (1) Brute force attacks become trivial - attackers can crack passwords with minimal compute resources and no rate limiting (combined with the "No Rate Limiting on Login Endpoint" vulnerability); (2) Dictionary attacks succeed easily - simple passwords like 'password', 'admin', '123456' can be cracked instantly; (3) Accounts are vulnerable to credential stuffing attacks; (4) User data can be easily compromised; (5) Attackers can hijack accounts to launch further attacks, steal data, or escalate privileges; (6) Compliance violations with security standards (NIST, PCI-DSS, etc.).
evidence:
Testing confirmed all weak passwords were accepted by the registration endpoint:

Test Results - All weak passwords accepted without validation errors:
- Password '1' (1 character): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password '12' (2 characters): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password '123' (3 characters): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password 'a' (1 letter): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password 'ab' (2 letters): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password 'abc' (3 letters): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password '' (empty): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password 'password' (common): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password 'admin' (common): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)
- Password '123456' (common): HTTP 200, Redirect (accepted)

No validation errors, complexity requirements, length restrictions, or rejections were encountered for any of the tested weak passwords. The application accepts all password inputs without any server-side validation.
remediation:
Implement a strong password policy to remediate this vulnerability:

1. **Enforce Minimum Password Length**: Require passwords of at least 12 characters (NIST recommendation) or minimum 8 characters as an absolute lower bound. Reject any registration with passwords shorter than this.

2. **Require Character Complexity**: Mandate a mix of character types:
   - At least one uppercase letter (A-Z)
   - At least one lowercase letter (a-z)
   - At least one numeric digit (0-9)
   - At least one special character (!@#$%^&*)

3. **Dictionary/Common Password Check**: Implement checks against:
   - OWASP password blacklist (https://github.com/danielmiessler/SecLists)
   - Common password lists
   - Previously breached password databases (e.g., Have I Been Pwned)
   - User's own information (username, email, name)

4. **Implement Password Strength Meter**: Provide real-time user feedback during registration to guide users toward stronger passwords.

5. **Secure Password Hashing**: Use bcrypt (recommended) or Argon2 for password hashing, never store plaintext or use weak algorithms like MD5 or SHA1.

6. **Combine with Rate Limiting**: Implement rate limiting on the login endpoint to prevent brute force attacks on weak passwords (as per "No Rate Limiting on Login Endpoint" finding).

7. **Follow NIST Guidelines**: Implement per NIST SP 800-63B: Minimum 8 characters for system-generated passwords, 12+ for user-chosen passwords.

Example implementation (pseudo-code):
```
if password_length < 12:
    reject("Password must be at least 12 characters")
if not contains_uppercase(password):
    reject("Password must contain uppercase letters")
if not contains_lowercase(password):
    reject("Password must contain lowercase letters")
if not contains_digit(password):
    reject("Password must contain numbers")
if not contains_special(password):
    reject("Password must contain special characters")
if check_common_passwords(password):
    reject("Password is too common")
```
references: OWASP: Authentication Cheat Sheet - https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authentication_Cheat_Sheet.html | NIST SP 800-63B: Digital Identity Guidelines - https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html | CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements - https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/521.html | CWE-307: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames - https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/307.html
